PIOTR:Â  Yeah, the first moment when I started thinking about it as a problem was Rails. And itâ€™s especially horrible in Rails due to the autoloading. So, one of the things that made me start to think about it as a problem was when I hit my first huge Rails app that was just so big that many, many places had to be refactored. And one of the reasons for that was that in Rails you can refer to any class anywhere. And it will be automatically loaded. So, you can accidentally without thinking much about it create a class that over time starts to depend on 12 other things, just because you can use it right there without the need to require it, without the need to instantiate it. But the end result is that you create so much coupling and you introduce so many dependencies inside your classes, completely without thinking about it. But in general when it comes to class interfaces I just like to be explicit about dependencies. So, when I have an object that has just too many things to do that I need to introduce some collaborators, I would always inject them in the constructor as objects. I would never instantiate them myself in the constructor. So, the object will not know how to instantiate its dependencies. And this technique was very helpful for me. And I realized that I always want to do it. I always want to use objects and introduce dependencies as objects, not classes, just because this makes me aware of dependencies and make dependencies very explicit. And also, once you start using objects rather than classes everywhere, there are a lot of nice benefits as a side effect. Like itâ€™s much easier to test things because you can easily use mocks in your tests. So yeah, these days Iâ€™m using classes, in mean class interfaces only to instantiate objects. PIOTR:Â  Yeah, so mutation testing is a technique where youâ€™re using a tool that loads your code, changes it in memory like at runtime, and then runs your tests. And the expectation is that some of those tests must fail. And if everything still passes, then youâ€™re missing some coverage. So, in Ruby we have a really good tool for that. Itâ€™s called Mutant. Iâ€™ve been using it since it was created I think two years ago. And yeah, itâ€™s Iâ€™d say an advanced technique. It requires a lot of time to learn how to do it properly. Probably the biggest problem with it is the tool that youâ€™re using, because it must run your tests and it must match which tests have to be run after changing some specific piece of your code. Because if you run all your tests, it might get very, very slow. So, thatâ€™s a challenge on the tool side. But itâ€™s also a challenge because you need to know what kinds of mutations are problematic for you. So, at least thatâ€™s my experience with Mutant. Itâ€™s the only tool that Iâ€™ve used so far in Ruby. Before that I used [Haskell]. But the general problem is to know which mutations are actually problematic, because if you want to achieve 100% mutation coverage itâ€™s just a lot of work. And it will slow you down drastically. So, I still find it extremely valuable because it can easily find bugs in your code. The only problem is that, at least thatâ€™s my opinion, that itâ€™s not something that you would like to do on a daily basis, especially if the code that youâ€™re writing is still changing a lot. Because it puts a huge emphasis on really good test coverage. So, the way I use it these days is that in my open source projects I would use Mutant before the release, again in specific parts of my code. And from one release to another the test coverage is getting better and better. And one thing, probably one of my favorite parts of mutation testing is that it actually helps a lot in removing your code. So, you can easily simplify your code and remove things that you donâ€™t actually need, because it shows you exactly all the places that are not covered by tests. And quite often, you may realize that, â€œOh, I actually donâ€™t need that,â€ and just remove something. So, itâ€™s a fantastic technique but it requires a lot of time to learn how to do it properly. DAVID:Â  Yeah. AVDI:Â  So, if thereâ€™s a line that canâ€™t cause a test failure even if itâ€™s changed or removed, that suggests that you might not even be using that line of code at all? PIOTR:Â  Yeah, exactly. AVDI:Â  Very cool. PIOTR:Â  Yeah, but itâ€™s tricky. Itâ€™s tricky, yeah. There are some cases where some mutation is not really necessary. But yeah, itâ€™s on the tool side. So, Mutant is getting better and better with each release. Itâ€™s just, it takes time to learn what kind of mutations you can safely skip if something isnâ€™t really a problem. Thatâ€™s why aiming for 100% coverage is just not reasonable. DAVID:Â  I find my biggest challenge with testing, even today, is eliminating duplication between my tests and my code. And what Iâ€™m trying to get towards is almost like a crosscheck. Iâ€™m old enough to have taken a bookkeeping class in high school for how to do tabulation and stenography and that sort of stuff. And one of the things that they have you do is that you crosscheck your work. So, if youâ€™re adding up columns of numbers, then you check your work by adding up the rows of numbers and then you sum up both sums. The sums of the columns should equal the sums of the rows. And if those two numbers donâ€™t equal, then you have a bug somewhere. And if you just sum up your columns a second time, like in your unit tests, basically thatâ€™s duplication. So, I try to build unit tests that will crosscheck my functionality rather than basically duplicating what my code is doing. It will actually basically say, â€œThis is what I expect you do,â€ rather than, â€œDo you do this step? Do you do this next step? Do you do this other step?â€ And I have to admit, I fear mutation testing because I canâ€™t, in my mind I canâ€™t see how I would do good mutation testing without duplicating a lot of my code in my tests. Is that a legitimate fear or am I just being spooked by something in my own imagination? PIOTR:Â  No, that sounds legit. It is a problem because as I said, itâ€™s related to the tool that youâ€™re using for mutation testing. As I mentioned, running the tests is the problem because it can be too slow. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important for the tool to find which tests run. And if you want to have very isolated tests that would cover everything, then you will end up with a lot of duplication in your code, in your tests. And Iâ€™ve experienced that myself. But it is possible to cover most of the mutations without the duplication. Itâ€™s just that you need to run the entire suite. DAVID:Â  Yeah. PIOTR:Â  Which can be just too slow. But yeah, itâ€™s still something that you can do against very specific parts of your code. DAVID:Â  Yeah. PIOTR:Â  So, I used it in a couple of projects just for specific parts. And it was extremely helpful there. DAVID:Â  Yeah. Yeah, I can definitely see how it would improve the thoroughness of your tests. PIOTR:Â  Oh yeah, definitely. DAVID:Â  So, weâ€™re getting close to needing to switch over to picks. But I donâ€™t want to do that until we talk about this last point in your blogpost, because I really think you saved the best for last, which I love. The last point in your blogpost is â€˜ideas behind ORM are a fallacyâ€™. AVDI:Â  Yeah. DAVID:Â  And I just want to give you the podium. Or Avdi, did you have something to add on the fire? [Go for it]. AVDI:Â  Well yeah. I just want to say, Iâ€™m absolutely looking forward to this because the last time we talked to you, you were neck-deep in implementing a for-real serious object relational mapper for Ruby. But that has changed course significantly since the last time we talked. So, Iâ€™m very curious about your thoughts there. PIOTR:Â  [Chuckles] Yeah. Oh, thatâ€™s true. Yeah, in general the main idea behind ORM is actually something that we need, especially in Ruby. In Ruby everything is an object, right? So, typically we represent data as hashes or array of hashes for example. So, we definitely need something that we know how to pull up the data from a database and just map it to the Ruby object. So, that part is obviously something that we need. But everything else is a horror for me these days. So, something that made me change my mind was that I spent a lot of time working on two ORMs basically. The first one was DataMapper. And then Ruby Object Mapper. Initially the project was supposed to be the actual DataMapper, the implementation of Data Mapper pattern. And the more I worked on it, the more I realized that itâ€™s just so much complexity. And it requires so much logic that it just made me start to question it. Do I really want to do it? Is it really worth the effort? And itâ€™s also related to the ideas behind immutability. So, the typical thing in Active Record for example is that the objects are mutable. So, you basically load a bunch of objects into memory. And then you change them. And then something needs to synchronize the state of those objects with the data that you have in your database. And that part alone is just extremely complicated. And to make things worse, we have a ton of additional functionality in Active Record and lots of other ORMs in Ruby. So, the way we do it is that we add even more complexity to something that is already extremely complicated. And [chuckles] what I learned about all those tiny little problems that must be solved, I just realized that itâ€™s just too much. And I donâ€™t want to build software based on something thatâ€™s so complicated. So, I just decided to do something thatâ€™s way simpler than that. And I realized that the most important thing for me is the actual data. And I want to really focus on that part. I just want something that makes it easy and efficient to get the data from the database and just load it into memory. And when I want to change something, I want something thatâ€™s separate from the reading, because thatâ€™s just a separate concern. And after time, after two months of thinking about it, I just decided to change ROM direction and rebuild it from scratch. And I decided to follow the command-query responsibility segregation which is about separating reading from writing. And so far, so good. Iâ€™m extremely happy with how it evolved. So yeah, thatâ€™s in a nutshell I guess. AVDI:Â  Iâ€™m trying to get my head around this. And I know we donâ€™t have a lot of time and itâ€™s going to be difficult to talk about, just hand-waving anyway. But I really want to understand this better. I know with traditional ORMs in order to read something from the database and then update it and then write it back, we usually have things like dirty tracking to know which fields in which objects were changed. How do you manage that kind of thing? Are you just explicitly writing back new copies of the records that you know youâ€™ve changed or what? PIOTR:Â  The way it works in ROM right now is that you have a command interface. Commands work with some input. So, essentially you have three steps. You receive some input. You need to perform some coercions, sanitize it, validate it. And then you just persist it. And if youâ€™re updating an existing record you can provide the original data tuple so that you can compare the input with the original one and decide whether or not some database operation is to be executed. But in ROM you donâ€™t load an object to change it somehow in memory and then get its state and then send it back to the database. Itâ€™s just very, very simplified. So, itâ€™s mostly focusing on dealing with the data itself. AVDI:Â  Very interesting. How far along would you say you are with this? Do you feel like youâ€™ve realized most of your vision so far? Or are you still getting started on it? PIOTR:Â  Iâ€™ve built a couple of projects already with ROM. So, I feel like itâ€™s a good direction. But there are some things that should be improved in terms of building queries and mapping more complex structures, especially when it comes to associations. But in general, Iâ€™m loving it, to be honest. Iâ€™m obviously biased. But so far, so good as I said. It feels really good. And I like the separation. I can clearly see that it simplifies a lot. It makes things more explicit. And also, in ROM itself itâ€™s just easier to work on it and evolve it when things are separated. I like the data-centric approach. I like that itâ€™s focused so much on the data. The way Iâ€™m using it these days is that I just load data into memory and represent them as simple Structs. And then I have some other objects that depend on the data structures and they do some work. So, it feels really good. I donâ€™t haveâ€¦ there are no callbacks, no lifecycle kind of stuff as we have in Active Record. Validation is separated. Data coercion is separated. Mapping is separated. Those are just small little pieces that work together. And the core concept in ROM is that you have a pipeline of data and you could change things, I mean change [inaudible] and map things in individual steps. And itâ€™s just easy to do it in ROM. So, when you have some relation it can send data through multiple mappers and decorate the data the way you want. I think that itâ€™s also easier to do DCI with ROM, because itâ€™s just so easy to decorate data with objects that are supposed to be used in individual contexts. So for example, if youâ€™re rendering something you can get the data from a relation and decorate it with some behavior that is needed for the rendering part. You can easily create presenters. You can easily create some objects that know what templates to render. Like one thing that I tried very simply in a Rails app was that I completely stopped using helpers to render views, to render HTML pieces. And I started using templates for everything. So, I basically load data and I decorate it with objects that know how to render individual elements of the user interface. And I absolutely loved it. I removed an entire layer from my app which is helpers, and I hate helpers. So, that felt really great. I think there are lots of things that you can do just differently once you focus on fetching data efficiently. And depending on very specific data structures as opposed to trying to design some abstract object that would, I donâ€™t know, be similar to the real world. Because it just doesnâ€™t work like that. So, Iâ€™m trying to focus much more on data and data processing, and simple decoration that is used in individual context. So for example, in ROM you wouldnâ€™t have a single user object. You would have, I donâ€™t know, a user renderer for the user interface or some JSON serializer. So yeah, itâ€™s just a different approach. I love it. Seriously. I think itâ€™s really refreshing and it opens up possibilities like lots of things can be done differently and more efficiently. AVDI:Â  Are there any projects, open source projects, where people can see examples of this in action? PIOTR:Â  Iâ€™m not sure, to be honest. I have a simple ROM demo in my account. To be honest, I donâ€™t know. [Chuckles] I would have to ask people. But the community is growing. More and more people are using it. So, I guess if we ask around, we would probably find something. But I know that people are starting using ROM in their projects at work. So, I think it works for more than just me.
